wikipedia_page.main: Sir Arthur Wilfred "Bill" Bonsall  (25 June 1917 – 26 November 2014) was director of the British signals intelligence agency, GCHQ—a post he held from 1973 to 1978.

response: *Sir Arthur Bonsall (born 1917), KCMG, Director of GCHQ, 1973–1978

link_mentions.page: List of people associated with Bletchley Park

response: The GCHQ director has become more publicly visible in the wake of the 2013 global surveillance disclosures. Sir Arthur Bonsall, director from 1973 to 1978, was the first director to speak publicly about his career at GCHQ when he was interviewed by the BBC in September 2013, and Sir Iain Lobban testified before parliament's Intelligence and Security Committee in the wake of the disclosures in November 2013. The director from 1989 to 1996, Sir John Adye, had previously spoken as a witness at the inquest into the death of Diana, Princess of Wales in February 2008 to deny that GCHQ had any involvement in the tape recordings that led to the "Camillagate" or "Squidgygate" scandals.

Bonsall was born on 31 March 1920, the youngest son of Wilfred C Bonsall and Sarah Frank. His older brother was Arthur Bonsall.Obituary He married Gillian Patrick, a Somerville graduate, in 1947. Bonsall and his wife were keen hill-walkers.Royal Society of Edinburgh obituary He wrote two articles for The Scottish Mountaineering Club on the definition of a Munro. After his retirement, Bonsall and his wife moved to Harrogate.
**Sir Arthur Bonsall, 97, civil servant, Director of GCHQ (1973–1978).
*Sir Arthur Bonsall, 97, British civil servant, Director of GCHQ (1973–1978).Sir Arthur Bonsall, former GCHQ director, dies aged 97
